oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Massacre
Winner of the Silver Star Tells of German Atrocity in the Battle of The Bulge
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Describes Hillary Martin's experience in the Battle of the Bulge, which earned him a Silver Star. Martin was a football player for MTSC in 1946

MASSACRE WINNER OF THE SILVER STAR TELLS OF GERMAN
ATROCITY IN THE BATTLE OF THE BULGE When the Blue Raiders take the field on
September 26 to open the first football
season at MTSC in four years-- two wearers
of the Silver Star awarded for gallantry in
action will be among the G.I. members of
the squad. Hilary Martin of Nashville won his
decoration in the famed Battle of the Bulge
by heroically calling on his battery to
shell the area in which he was acting as
forward observer in an effort to cover the
withdrawal of nine survivors of A company
of the 23rd Infantry Regiment. Martin, a staff sergeant with Battery A of
the 434th regiment of trapped in a salient
north of St. Vith on December 21-22, 1944
and after all but nine men of the 240 men
who had been committed to action with him
had become casualties he crawled into an
abandoned machine gun emplacement and
operating his radio to direct artillery
fire from his battery while he
intermittently fired the gun to cover the
withdrawal of the shattered remnants of the
company to which he had come to command by
virtue of being the senior non-com left. Called for Fire on Self Receiving the code message from his colonel
that the battery fire power was all but
exhausted Martin asked for fire to be laid
down right on top of his own position to
slow the German advance. Abandoning his radio, helmet, and battle
jacket, Martin withdrew from his forward
observers and for five days, armed only
with a side-arm and his slain lieutenant's
map case he worked his way back through the
German lines to rejoin his outfit. Enroute he ran across a private from
Philadelphia suffering from battle fatigue
and determined to evacuate him. Digging
into a snow bank near Malmandy to avoid
traveling by day he was within 125 yards of
the scene of the butchery of 135 medics. Describes German Atrocity "The Hienes had captured these boys and had
lined them up as though they were going to
march them back when two German tanks drew
over a little hill and machine gunned them.
Then the Heines walked about among the
bodies, kicking and shooting any who showed
signs of life. Later I saw one of the few
who survived that massacre and he couldn't
even hold a cigarette," Martin said. The Philadelphia youth was holed in with
Martin during those harrowing minutes. "I
had to keep him from crying and try to keep
his morale up, so I didn't have much time
to worry about myself," Martin explains
modestly. Back to the American lines Martin was sent
to a medical aid unit to recuperate from
frost bite and exposure. Two days later he
was back with his outfit and accompanied (Continued On Page Two) MORE ABOUT Massacre (Continued From Page One) them on their re-occupation of St. Vith. He wears five battle stars among his
decorations.
